verses.text: When Balaam saw that it pleased the Lord to bless Israel, he did not go, as at other times, to seek omens, but set his face toward the wilderness.
verses.comment: The phrase 'seek omens' reflects the original language's mention of divination (Hebrew: nahash).

verses.text: And Balaam lifted up his eyes and saw Israel camped tribe by tribe. And the Spirit of God came upon him.
verses.comment: The phrase 'lifted up his eyes' is a literal translation from Hebrew.

verses.text: And he spoke his oracle and said: 'The oracle of Balaam the son of Beor, the oracle of the man whose eyes are opened,'
verses.comment: 'Oracle' renders the Hebrew 'massa' meaning 'utterance' or 'burden'.

verses.text: 'The oracle of him who hears the words of God, who sees the vision of the Almighty, falling down with eyes uncovered:'
verses.comment: The phrase 'falling down with eyes uncovered' means in a prophetic trance.

verses.text: 'How beautiful are your tents, O Jacob, your dwellings, O Israel!'
verses.comment: Literal rendering of Hebrew poetic expression.

verses.text: 'Like valleys that spread out, like gardens beside a river, like aloes that the Lord has planted, like cedar trees beside the waters.'
verses.comment: 'Aloes' refers to fragrant trees, not the modern aloe plant.

verses.text: 'Water will flow from his buckets, and his seed will be in many waters. His king will be greater than Agag; and his kingdom will be exalted.'
verses.comment: 'Seed' here means descendants or offspring.

verses.text: 'God brings him out of Egypt. He has the strength of a wild ox; he will devour the nations, his enemies, and will crush their bones and pierce them with his arrows.'
verses.comment: 'Wild ox' (Hebrew: re'em) may refer to a now-extinct animal.

verses.text: 'He crouched, he lay down like a lion, and like a lioness; who will rouse him? Blessed is he who blesses you, and cursed is he who curses you.'
verses.comment: Echoes the promise to Abraham in Genesis 12:3.

verses.text: Then Balak’s anger burned against Balaam, and he struck his hands together. And Balak said to Balaam, 'I called you to curse my enemies, but you have blessed them these three times.'
verses.comment: Striking hands together was a gesture of anger or frustration.

verses.text: 'Now therefore, flee to your own place! I said I would greatly honor you, but the Lord has kept you from honor.'
verses.comment: Balak refers to the Lord, acknowledging His sovereignty.

verses.text: And Balaam said to Balak, 'Did I not also tell your messengers whom you sent to me,'
verses.comment: Balaam recalls his previous statements.

verses.text: 'If Balak would give me his house full of silver and gold, I could not go beyond the command of the Lord, to do either good or bad from my own heart. What the Lord speaks, that I will speak?'
verses.comment: Faithfulness to God's command is emphasized.

verses.text: 'And now, indeed, I am going to my people. Come, I will give you advice about what this people will do to your people in the latter days.'
verses.comment: 'Latter days' refers to future times; this is a prophecy.

verses.text: And he took up his oracle and said: 'The oracle of Balaam son of Beor, the oracle of the man whose eyes are opened,'
verses.comment: Repetition for poetic structure; Hebrew matches previous oracle.

verses.text: 'The oracle of him who hears the words of God, and knows the knowledge of the Most High, who sees the vision of the Almighty, falling down with eyes uncovered:'
verses.comment: 'Most High' (Heb. Elyon); Balaam as prophet.

verses.text: 'I see him, but not now; I behold him, but not near. A star shall come out of Jacob, and a scepter will arise out of Israel; it will crush the forehead of Moab and break down all the sons of Sheth.'
verses.comment: 'Star' and 'scepter' are symbolic of a king; 'sons of Sheth' is a debated phrase, possibly meaning 'sons of tumult.'

verses.text: 'Edom will be dispossessed; Seir, his enemies, also will be dispossessed. Israel will do valiantly.'
verses.comment: 'Seir' refers to the land of Edom.

verses.text: 'One from Jacob will have dominion and destroy the survivors of cities.'
verses.comment: This refers to a coming ruler from Israel.

verses.text: When he looked on Amalek, he took up his oracle and said: 'Amalek was the first among the nations, but his end is utter destruction.'
verses.comment: Amalek is referenced as ancient and doomed.

verses.text: Then he looked on the Kenite, and took up his oracle and said: 'Strong is your dwelling place, and your nest is set in the rock,'
verses.comment: 'Nest is set in the rock' is a metaphor for security.

verses.text: 'Nevertheless, the Kenite will be wasted; Asshur shall carry you away captive.'
verses.comment: 'Asshur' refers to the Assyrians.

verses.text: And he took up his oracle and said: 'Alas, who shall live when God does this?'
verses.comment: An expression of amazement or lament.

verses.text: 'But ships will come from Kittim and will afflict Asshur and will afflict Eber, and so he also will perish forever.'
verses.comment: 'Kittim' often refers to Cyprus or western lands; prophecy about future invaders.

verses.text: Then Balaam rose and went back to his place, and Balak also went his way.
verses.comment: Concludes the Balaam narrative in this context.
